q:
In Selenium, you are working with the waits. You have imported the following package to include an implicit wait in your test scripts. If you have executed the following code in your test script, then which of the following statements about this code in this scenario is correct:

Package

import java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit;

Code

driver.manage().timeouts().implicitlyWait(10, TimeUnit.SECONDS);

a.option: It is used to set an implicit wait before the instantiation of a WebDriver instance variable.
It is used to set an implicit wait after the instantiation of a WebDriver instance variable.

q:
In Selenium, if you are working with waits, then which of the following statements about the Implicit waits are correct:

  1. An implicit wait is to indicate the WebDriver to poll the DOM for a certain amount of time when trying to find an element or elements if they are not immediately available. 
  2. Mixing of an explicit wait and an implicit wait can increase the stability of the DOM element.
  3. Implicit waiting for elements to appear is disabled by default and will need to be manually enabled on a per-session basis.

In Selenium, if you are working with waits, then which of the following statements about the Explicit waits are correct:

  1. They are available to Selenium clients for imperative, procedural languages. 
  2. They allow your code to halt program execution, or freeze the thread, until the condition you pass it resolves.
  3. This is used when certain elements on the webpage are not available immediately and need some time to load.

In Selenium, which of these statements about the following FluentWait command are correct:

Command

Wait wait = new FluentWait<WebDriver>(driver)
.withTimeout(50, TimeUnit.SECONDS)
.pollingevery(3, TimeUnit.SECONDS)
.ignoring(NoSuchElementException.class);

Statements

  1. This command is operated on two parameters named the timeout value and polling frequency.
  2. This command directs the WebDriver to wait a maximum of 3 seconds to verify a specific condition.
  3. If the condition doesn’t occur during the 50 seconds, this command throws an ElementNotVisibleException.

In Selenium, you are working with the waits. Assume that you have included your explicit script into your test scripts by importing the following packages. If you are required to initialize a wait object by using the WebDriverWait class such that the Selenium WebDriver waits for 30 seconds before it throws a TimeOutException, then which of the following syntax is used to perform this action in this scenario:

Packages

import org.openqa.selenium.support.ui.ExpectedConditions
import org.openqa.selenium.support.ui.WebDriverWait

In Selenium, you are trying to synchronize the states between the browser and its DOM by using an explicit wait. If you are required to check if the WebElement with a given locator has an attribute that contains a specific value, then which of the following Java expected methods of the class ExpectedConditions is used to perform this action?

a.option: attributeContains(By locator, java.lang.String attribute, java.lang.String value)

q: In Selenium, which of the following wait instances defines the maximum amount of time to wait for a condition, as well as the frequency with which to check the condition?

In Selenium, which of the following statements about the difference between implicit wait and explicit wait are correct:

  1. Implicit wait applies only to specific elements as intended by the user whereas an explicit wait applies to all the elements in a test script.
  2. Explicit wait applies only to specific elements as intended by the user whereas an implicit wait applies to all the elements in a test script.
  3. ExpectedConditions are not required to be specified in an implicit wait for the elements that are to be located whereas they are required to be specified in an explicit wait.
